prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 1
Name: Ernest Amano
Description: Benefactor when I studied in Germany. Director of the Amano Group.
Character 2
Name: Lance Amano
Description: Son of Ernest Amano. Victim of the kidnapping. I knew him when he was a child.
Character 3
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: Self-purported Great Thief. She suddenly appeared, but why was she stalking me?
Character 4
Name: Shi-Long Lang
Description: An Interpol Agent. He is in charge of this kidnapping case for some odd reason.
Character 5
Name: Shih-na
Description: Lang's trusty secretary. Level-headed, she supports him in his investigations.
Character 6
Name: Oliver Deacon
Description: Amano family butler, and Lance's private tutor. Could not be contacted recently.
Character 7
Name: Mike Meekins
Description: Precinct police officer. Was conducting investigation while in Blue Badger costume.
Character 8
Name: Lauren Paups
Description: Lance Amano's girlfriend. Came to Gatewater Land in search of Lance.
Character 9
Name: Ema Skye
Description: High schooler in Europe to become forensic scientist. On school break.
Character 10
Name: Security Lady
Description: The lady inside the Pink Badger. I believe her real name is Wendy Oldbag.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 1
Name: Gatewater Land Pamphlet
Description: Map and explanation of park attractions listed.
Evidence 2
Name: Bad Badger's Head
Description: Costumes separate into head and body. This head was left in the Isolation Room.
Evidence 3
Name: Blue Badger Bible
Description: Book detailing info on the whole Badger family.
Evidence 4
Name: Badger Photo Rally
Description: There's only 1 of each Badger in the park. Try to get the whole Badger family!
Evidence 5
Name: Stolen Costumes
Description: The kidnappers stole three costumes: a Blue, a Proto and a Bad Badger. Blue Badger = Lauren Paups Proto Badger = Lance Amano Bad Badger = Oliver Deacon
Evidence 6
Name: Preliminary Findings → Mr. Deacon's Murder Notes
Description: Victim: Oliver Deacon. Seems he was shot dead. Victim, Deacon, shot from ABD through shoulder. Body was moved. Shot from ABD through shoulder.
Evidence 7
Name: Mr. Deacon's Pendant
Description: It's shaped like a horse. "Colin Devorae" is engraved on the back.
Evidence 8
Name: Blue Badgermobile
Description: Mobile shop on three wheels. Was parked inside Wild, Wild West area garage.
Evidence 9
Name: Victim's Costume
Description: He was likely wearing one due to the footprints' shape and the lack of blood. Worn at the time of the shooting. Gunpowder burn is proof he was shot from point blank.
Evidence 10
Name: Love Letter
Description: Letter for Lance Amano. The sender is the "Tender Lender Loan Company".
Evidence 11
Name: Colin Devorae Dossier
Description: Details Oliver Deacon's real name and history. [info]Caolin Devorae
Sex: Male
Dominant Hand: Right
Height: 5'8"
Weight: 123.45 lbs

Whereabouts unknown after his escape from Penn E. Dent Prison. Stole a gun from a guard during his scape. We thought he might head for where his wife and sole daughter are, but despite our surveillance, he has yet to show up.
Evidence 12
Name: Broken Prop Sword
Description: Was used to jam the handle to the hideout's door from the inside. Culprit hit me in the right temple area with this.
Evidence 13
Name: Missing Model Gun
Description: Was ripped from the Bad Badger costume. It's capable of firing blanks.
Evidence 14
Name: Ms. Paups's Pendant
Description: It's shaped like a pair of wings. "Lauren D." is engraved on the back.
Evidence 15
Name: Revolver
Description: Used to kill Deacon. Was originally stolen from guard by victim during escape.
Evidence 16
Name: Mirror Fragments
Description: These were found inside the victim's costume. Why were they there in the first place? Different from the mirrors on the walls. Very thick and has a design on the back.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I'll grant you that the two of them are father and daughter.
Person: Lang
Testimony 1
Testimony: But, isn't it possible that they both knew that fact?
Person: Lang
Testimony 2
Testimony: It was no coincidence that the reunited pair became involved in the house of Amano.
Person: Lang
Testimony 3
Testimony: And the two of them made good use of their meetings to plan this little kidnapping.
Person: Lang
Testimony 4
Testimony: Wouldn't you say my scenario is perfectly probable as well?
Person: Lang

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants me to look through the provided evidence and testimonies to find a pair that conflicts. Let's start by reviewing the testimonies first.

The testimonies are all from Lang. Testimony 3 says: "And the two of them made good use of their meetings to plan this little kidnapping." So Lang is suggesting that two people (father and daughter, from earlier testimonies) planned the kidnapping together. But which evidence would contradict this?

Looking at the evidence, Evidence 5 mentions that the stolen costumes were used by Lauren Paups (Blue Badger), Lance Amano (Proto Badger), and Oliver Deacon (Bad Badger). However, Evidence 6 states that Oliver Deacon was shot dead. If Deacon is a victim of murder, he couldn't have been part of the kidnapping plot as a perpetrator. So if Lang's Testimony 3 is saying that the two (possibly Deacon and someone else, like Lauren) planned the kidnapping, but Deacon was actually killed, that would be a contradiction. 

Wait, let's check Evidence 6 again. The preliminary findings note that Oliver Deacon was shot dead. His body was moved, and he was shot from point blank. So he's a murder victim. If he's dead, he couldn't have been involved in planning the kidnapping after his death. But according to Evidence 5, the Bad Badger costume (Deacon's) was stolen, implying he was part of the kidnapping. But if he's dead, maybe he was killed before or during the kidnapping. 

But Testimony 3 says "the two of them" planned the kidnapping. If one of them is Deacon, but he's dead, that's a contradiction. Alternatively, maybe the two are someone else. Let's check other evidence. 

Evidence 7 is a pendant of Deacon's with "Colin Devorae" engraved, and Evidence 11 is a dossier on Colin Devorae, which is Deacon's real name. He was an escaped prisoner who stole a gun. Evidence 15 says the revolver used to kill Deacon was the same gun he stole. So Deacon was killed with his own stolen gun. 

If Deacon was killed, then he couldn't be part of the kidnapping plot. So Lang's testimony 3, which implicates two people (maybe Deacon and Lauren?) in planning the kidnapping, is contradicted by the fact that Deacon was murdered. Therefore, Testimony 3's claim that both were involved in planning is contradicted by Evidence 6 (Deacon's murder). 

Alternatively, maybe the two are Lauren and someone else. But Lauren's pendant (Evidence 14) is "Lauren D." which might connect her to Deacon (if D stands for Devorae), implying she's his daughter. If Lang's testimonies suggest that Lauren and Deacon (father and daughter) planned the kidnapping, but Deacon was killed, then that's a contradiction. So Testimony 3 claims they planned it together, but Evidence 6 shows Deacon was murdered, so he couldn't be a co-conspirator. 

So the contradiction would be between Testimony 3 (they planned the kidnapping) and Evidence 6 (Deacon was killed). Therefore, the correct pair is Evidence 6 and Testimony 3. Wait, but Evidence 5 says the stolen costumes include Deacon's. Maybe he was part of the kidnapping but then killed. But the testimony says they planned it together. If Deacon was part of the kidnapping but then killed by someone else, maybe the plan went wrong. However, the testimony says they made use of their meetings to plan the kidnapping. If Deacon was killed, he couldn't have continued to be part of the plan. But perhaps the contradiction is more direct. Let me check again.

Testimony 3: "the two of them made good use of their meetings to plan this little kidnapping." If the two are Deacon and Lauren (as father and daughter), but Deacon was murdered, then he couldn't have been planning with her if he was dead. The evidence of his murder (Evidence 6) would contradict the testimony that he was involved in planning. So Evidence 6 (Deacon's murder) contradicts Testimony 3 (they planned the kidnapping together). Therefore, the correct answer is Evidence 6 and Testimony 3. But wait, the evidence numbers: Evidence 6 is Mr. Deacon's Murder Notes, which state he was shot dead and body moved. So if he's dead, how could he be part of the planning? So the pair is Evidence 6 and Testimony 3. Let me confirm once more. Yes, because Testimony 3 implies both were alive and planning, but Evidence 6 shows Deacon is dead, making that impossible.

cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. The user wants me to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The key is to go through each testimony and see if any evidence directly contradicts it.

First, I'll list out all the testimonies by Lance. Testimony 3 says: "My hands were cuffed, but it was a stroke of luck that they left me alone." So he claims his hands were cuffed. Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 12 is the Broken Prop Sword, which was used to jam the door handle from the inside. The description mentions that Lance was tied up when he woke up. Wait, the testimony says cuffed, but the evidence from Lance's own statement in Evidence 12 says he was "all tied up." That's a contradiction. Handcuffs (cuffed) versus being tied up. So Testimony 3 says cuffed, but Evidence 12's note from Lance says he was tied. Therefore, Evidence 12 contradicts Testimony 3.

Another possible angle: Testimony 0 says he was kidnapped yesterday morning, but any evidence about timing? Not sure. Let's check others. Testimony 2 mentions kidnappers disappeared when it rained. Any evidence about weather? Not that I see. The main contradiction I found earlier seems solid. So the pair would be Evidence 12 and Testimony 3.

cot:
Okay, let's start by looking at the evidence and testimonies provided. The task is to find a contradiction between one piece of evidence and one testimony.

First, I'll review the testimonies given by Lauren Paups (Testimony 0 to 4). Testimony 2 says that the Bad Badger pointed the gun with his left hand. However, looking at the evidence, Evidence 11 is the Colin Devorae Dossier, which mentions that Oliver Deacon (whose real name is Colin Devorae) is right-handed. Since Oliver Deacon was the one in the Bad Badger costume (as per Evidence 5), he would use his dominant right hand to hold the gun. But Testimony 2 claims the gun was in the left hand. That's a contradiction because a right-handed person would typically use their right hand, especially in a stressful situation like aiming a gun. 

Another point to check: Evidence 15 states the revolver used was stolen by the victim (Deacon) during his escape, which aligns with him having the gun. So the contradiction here is between the handedness in the dossier and the testimony about the left hand. Therefore, Evidence 11 and Testimony 2 contradict each other.

cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. I need to look through all the provided information and find inconsistencies.

First, the testimonies from Lance (Testimonies 0-3) all seem to point towards Lolli acting in self-defense. Specifically, Testimony 1 says that the fingerprints on the gun prove Lolli killed Oliver. But Testimony 3 claims that Lolli was acting in self-defense because Oliver was after her life.

Now, looking at the evidence. Evidence 15 is the Revolver used to kill Deacon, which was originally stolen from a guard by the victim (Oliver Deacon) during his escape. Wait, the revolver was stolen by the victim himself, so he had the gun. But if Oliver was the one who had the gun, how could Lolli (maybe Lauren or someone else) have used it in self-defense? Also, Evidence 6 (Preliminary Findings) states that Deacon was shot from point blank based on the gunpowder burn, and the body was moved. 

But the key contradiction is in Testimony 1 where Lance says the fingerprints on the gun prove Lolli killed Oliver. However, Evidence 15 says the revolver was stolen by Oliver (the victim) during his escape. If Oliver had the gun, then his own fingerprints would be on it. But if Lolli used it to shoot him, her fingerprints might be there too. However, Testimony 1 claims the fingerprints are Lolli's, which might not make sense if Oliver was the one who had the gun. Wait, but the revolver was used to kill Deacon (Oliver Deacon), so maybe there's confusion here. Let me check the evidence again.

Wait, Evidence 6's victim is Oliver Deacon. He was shot with the revolver (Evidence 15), which was stolen by the victim (Deacon) from a guard. So the gun belonged to Deacon. If Lolli used Deacon's own gun to kill him, then her fingerprints would be on it. But if Deacon was the one who stole it, his prints would be there too. But Testimony 1 says the fingerprints prove Lolli did it, implying her prints are on the gun. However, if Deacon had the gun, then maybe his prints should also be present. But perhaps the contradiction is that the revolver (Evidence 15) was stolen by Deacon, so if he was killed with his own gun, the presence of his fingerprints wouldn't necessarily implicate someone else. Alternatively, if the gun only has Lolli's prints, that contradicts because Deacon should have handled it too. But maybe that's not the case.

Alternatively, let's look at Testimony 3 where Lance claims self-defense because Oliver was after Lolli. But Evidence 6 says the victim (Deacon) was shot from point blank (gunpowder burn) and the body was moved. If it's self-defense, the shooting would likely be at a distance, not point blank. So the gunpowder burn suggests the shooter was very close, which contradicts a self-defense scenario where the attacker (Oliver) would have been approaching, and the shooter (Lolli) would fire from a distance. Therefore, Testimony 3 (self-defense) contradicts Evidence 6's finding of a point-blank shot.

So the contradiction is between Testimony 3 (self-defense) and Evidence 6 (point-blank shot, which implies the shooter was close, possibly not self-defense). Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 6 and Testimony 3. But wait, Evidence 6's description mentions that the victim was shot from ABD through the shoulder, body moved, and shot from point blank. The gunpowder burn indicates proximity. If it's self-defense, the shooter might not have been that close. So Lance's claim of self-defense (Testimony 3) is contradicted by Evidence 6's point-blank evidence, which suggests it wasn't self-defense but a deliberate close-range shooting.
